message_1: Consider the topological space X = {a, b, c, d} with the topology T = {∅, {a}, {a, b}, X}. Is this space a regular space? If yes, prove it. If no, provide a counterexample.
message_2:
No, this space is not a regular space. To show this, we will provide a counterexample.

Recall that a topological space X is regular if for every closed set C and a point x ∈ X \ C, there exist disjoint open sets U and V such that x ∈ U and C ⊆ V.

Consider the closed set C = {c, d} and the point x = b. Note that x ∉ C. We will show that there are no disjoint open sets U and V such that x ∈ U and C ⊆ V.

The open sets containing x = b are {a, b} and X. If we choose U = {a, b}, then any open set V containing C must also contain b, since the only open set containing both c and d is X. If we choose U = X, then U and V cannot be disjoint, as V must contain all elements of X.

Thus, there are no disjoint open sets U and V such that x ∈ U and C ⊆ V, which means that the topological space X is not regular.
